newsitem.title: UK: N Sea offshore loading crudes rise with freight.
newsitem.headline: N Sea offshore loading crudes rise with freight.

text.p: North Sea crudes which load offshore jumped in value on Tuesday as freight rates soared during the day, traders said.
Statfjord, valued in the low dated Brent +40 cents early in the day, traded later at dated +51 cents and some thought a cargo moved as high as dated Brent +60 cents.
"World scale has gone mad. You can't get ships. World scale for the October 23-28 time range shot up over lunch today. A cargo fixed on Monday at 115 would cost you 135 today," one trader said.
November IPE Brent dipped 22 cents by 1738 GMT to $24.64.
Offshore loading crudes Statfjord, Draugen and Gullfaks have freight rates for set destinations set at the beginning of the year and thus do not fluctuate with movements on worldscale.
The November Brent crude oil loading programme was expected to be released overnight.

Other physical North Sea deals included two October Brent cargoes - at November -8 and -5 cents, a Nov 9-11 Troll at dated +60 cents, November 6-10 Draugen at dated +50 cents and a Urals at dated -55 cents cif NWE (Nov 1-5 delivery).
Talk of an October 31-02 Forties at dated Brent +48 cents could not be confirmed, but was thought around market level.
The ULCC fixed to load some five Brent cargoes around October 25 for the U.S. Gulf took all the remaining October barrels out of the market, traders said.
"It has tightened things up but whether the dated Brent value will rise above the current level (Nov -5 cents) I don't know. It doesn't feel like it will fall," one producer said.
Urals supply/demand in the north and the Mediterranean was balanced, traders said.
In the North delays of 1-2 days continued but buying was subdued and assessed around dated Brent -52/55 cents.
